Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 1 (Full-Time) 2025-26

Org Unit:Biosciences
Level:Level 7

Module Code:BIOM703
Delivery:University of Liverpool · Semester 1

BIOM703
Notes
The purpose of this module is to facilitate the acquisition of advanced knowledge and skills in the planning of an empirical research project in one of the listed research pathways. In addition, students will develop additional skills in critical understanding, knowledge of research techniques, together with presentation and other transferable skills to enhance employability.

The research pathways are:

Biology of Cancer
Biomedical Imaging and Biosensing
Cancer Medicine
Cellular and Molecular Physiology
Medical Sciences
Molecular and Clinical Gastroenterology
Pharmacology and Therapeutics
Neuroscience
Stem Cells, Tissues and Disease

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine provides students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the programme. Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The programme is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interesting in training in biological sciences.

Students will become full members of a research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment. This module along with the 80 credit Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704) module are designed to allow for a parity of experience between the part-time and full-time programmes and clear progression of research education.

This is a 40-credit module that gives direct authentic research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report and preparing an oral presentation. The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal and an oral presentation, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will also be provided with insight into relevant research techniques required for the project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project in Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704). Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given via Science Skills sessions in the BIOM604 module, supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Assessment of the module is via the preliminary report and oral presentation, along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the pathway lead to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address a novel area of research related to one of the programme pathways, but this covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1. To provide students with training in appropriate techniques, research methods and project management in order to conduct a novel research project on aspects of biomedical and translational sciences within an active, first class research environment.

2 To provide the opportunity for students to experience cutting-edge research, and to provide an up-to-date understanding of recent developments and applications in areas of biomedical and translational sciences.

3. To enable students to develop a range of complementary research and employability skills which will provide them with the skills needed to pursue a research career or other professional employment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The MRes in Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine provides students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB). Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The programme is suitable for bioscience graduates, intercalating medical and veterinary students, and science graduates interesting in training in biological sciences. Students will become full members of a research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment.

This is a 40 credit module that gives direct authentic research experience. The module represents the first part of a two-part research project within the MRes in Biomedical Science and Translational Medicine programme. The teaching approach relies upon research-connected and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of scientific reports, scientific presentations, continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Outline Syllabus
All students will work on a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project. Projects will offer diverse experiences in research techniques, governance, project management and analysis in an area of Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine. Identification of individual development needs by Training Needs Analysis meetings (with supervisor and module lead) will be combined with self-reflections in a skills portfolio. Online resources will support self-directed learning. Students will be given initial training in relevant research techniques required for the project, but will develop the ability to work independently as the project progresses in Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704). Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation is given via Science Skills sessions in the BIOM604 module, supplemented by project-specific guidance via the academic project supervisor.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The ethos of the learning and teaching in this module is to ensure teaching is informed and refreshed by research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching and supervision will be undertaken by researchers in their specialist area. The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of biomedical sciences with research (Research connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students are expected to spend most of their time critically reviewing the literature, planning and piloting their research, and preparing communications i.e. preliminary report, and oral presentations. Regular meetings with the project supervisor(s) are required to ensure students are properly guided and provided with constructive feedback on progress and assignments. Learning will involve self, and supervisor supported, reflection skills activities, followed by evidencing and further portfolio-aided reflection in order to support personalised skills development. In addition to recommended weekly supervisor meetings there will be 2 formal meetings to support portfolio development. Digital resources including videos, workshops and recommended literature also support student learning. The module builds on their understanding of research processes, experimental design, conducting and analysing an empirical research project, research governance and scientific communications via the research project. Laboratory teaching will be undertaken by an experienced member of staff. Once competent, students will undertake the laboratory work under supervision and finally independently or as part of a larger group.

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Supervisors will guide the students through the research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project, in a research report format (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The Departmental research environment and informal teaching sessions - introduce new learning, reinforcing prior learning around research and methodologies and guide the student through their learning process.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. Discussion between students and research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

This teaching and learning strategy, tailored to the specific needs of the student, will help them further develop their specialist research knowledge and understanding, critical thinking skills and research skills. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by submission of a preliminary project report, an oral presentation to peers and members of the Institute and completion of an individual reflective skills portfolio which forms part of the continual assessment. Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft opportunity. The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project. The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. However, all proposals will be independently second marked by someone who hasn’t been involved in the delivery of the project. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report being an outline proposal which would be common in requesting funding for a pilot study and would include a hypothesis, supporting evidence aimed to encourage critical analysis of the literature, development of a feasible project idea and understanding. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis, discussion of findings in relation to the field of research.

Students will be offered a re-assessment opportunity in failed assessments in accordance with COPA Appendix C.

Students resitting the oral presentation component will be able to present on their project.

Students resitting the preliminary report will be allowed to re-submit on their project.

Students resitting the module will be required to develop a completely new project with a new supervisor.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Deliveries

 LocationPeriod 
 
Liverpool campus
Semester 1


Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Plan an original research study in the field of biomedical sciences within a specified time frame.
 LO2 Critically evaluate appropriate research techniques, when designing a biomedical sciences research project.
 LO3 Critically appraise relevant literature in the field of biomedical sciences, utilising insights when designing an original research project.
 LO4 Communicate project ideas and principles to a scientific audience.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning.
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations.
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks.

 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks.

Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 1 (Full-Time)

BIOM703
Notes
The purpose of this module is to facilitate the acquisition of advanced knowledge and skills in the planning of an empirical research project in one of the listed research pathways. In addition, students will develop additional skills in critical understanding, knowledge of research techniques, together with presentation and other transferable skills to enhance employability.

The research pathways are:

Biology of Cancer
Biomedical Imaging and Biosensing
Cancer Medicine
Cellular and Molecular Physiology
Medical Sciences
Molecular and Clinical Gastroenterology
Pharmacology and Therapeutics
Neuroscience
Stem Cells, Tissues and Disease

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine provides students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the programme. Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The programme is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interesting in training in biological sciences.

Students will become full members of a research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment. This module along with the 80 credit Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704) module are designed to allow for a parity of experience between the part-time and full-time programmes and clear progression of research education.

This is a 40-credit module that gives direct authentic research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report and preparing an oral presentation. The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal and an oral presentation, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will also be provided with insight into relevant research techniques required for the project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project in Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704). Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given via Science Skills sessions in the BIOM604 module, supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Assessment of the module is via the preliminary report and oral presentation, along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the pathway lead to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address a novel area of research related to one of the programme pathways, but this covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1. To provide students with training in appropriate techniques, research methods and project management in order to conduct a novel research project on aspects of biomedical and translational sciences within an active, first class research environment.

2 To provide the opportunity for students to experience cutting-edge research, and to provide an up-to-date understanding of recent developments and applications in areas of biomedical and translational sciences.

3. To enable students to develop a range of complementary research and employability skills which will provide them with the skills needed to pursue a research career or other professional employment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The MRes in Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine provides students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB). Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The programme is suitable for bioscience graduates, intercalating medical and veterinary students, and science graduates interesting in training in biological sciences. Students will become full members of a research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment.

This is a 40 credit module that gives direct authentic research experience. The module represents the first part of a two-part research project within the MRes in Biomedical Science and Translational Medicine programme. The teaching approach relies upon research-connected and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of scientific reports, scientific presentations, continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Outline Syllabus
All students will work on a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project. Projects will offer diverse experiences in research techniques, governance, project management and analysis in an area of Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine. Identification of individual development needs by Training Needs Analysis meetings (with supervisor and module lead) will be combined with self-reflections in a skills portfolio. Online resources will support self-directed learning. Students will be given initial training in relevant research techniques required for the project, but will develop the ability to work independently as the project progresses in Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704). Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation is given via Science Skills sessions in the BIOM604 module, supplemented by project-specific guidance via the academic project supervisor.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The ethos of the learning and teaching in this module is to ensure teaching is informed and refreshed by research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching and supervision will be undertaken by researchers in their specialist area. The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of biomedical sciences with research (Research connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students are expected to spend most of their time critically reviewing the literature, planning and piloting their research, and preparing communications i.e. preliminary report, and oral presentations. Regular meetings with the project supervisor(s) are required to ensure students are properly guided and provided with constructive feedback on progress and assignments. Learning will involve self, and supervisor supported, reflection skills activities, followed by evidencing and further portfolio-aided reflection in order to support personalised skills development. In addition to recommended weekly supervisor meetings there will be 2 formal meetings to support portfolio development. Digital resources including videos, workshops and recommended literature also support student learning. The module builds on their understanding of research processes, experimental design, conducting and analysing an empirical research project, research governance and scientific communications via the research project. Laboratory teaching will be undertaken by an experienced member of staff. Once competent, students will undertake the laboratory work under supervision and finally independently or as part of a larger group.

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Supervisors will guide the students through the research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project, in a research report format (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The Departmental research environment and informal teaching sessions - introduce new learning, reinforcing prior learning around research and methodologies and guide the student through their learning process.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. Discussion between students and research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

This teaching and learning strategy, tailored to the specific needs of the student, will help them further develop their specialist research knowledge and understanding, critical thinking skills and research skills. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by submission of a preliminary project report, an oral presentation to peers and members of the Institute and completion of an individual reflective skills portfolio which forms part of the continual assessment. Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft opportunity. The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project. The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. However, all proposals will be independently second marked by someone who hasn’t been involved in the delivery of the project. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report being an outline proposal which would be common in requesting funding for a pilot study and would include a hypothesis, supporting evidence aimed to encourage critical analysis of the literature, development of a feasible project idea and understanding. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis, discussion of findings in relation to the field of research.

Students will be offered a re-assessment opportunity in failed assessments in accordance with COPA Appendix C.

Students resitting the oral presentation component will be able to present on their project.

Students resitting the preliminary report will be allowed to re-submit on their project.

Students resitting the module will be required to develop a completely new project with a new supervisor.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Deliveries

 LocationPeriod 
 
Liverpool campus
Semester 1


Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Plan an original research study in the field of biomedical sciences within a specified time frame.
 LO2 Critically evaluate appropriate research techniques, when designing a biomedical sciences research project.
 LO3 Critically appraise relevant literature in the field of biomedical sciences, utilising insights when designing an original research project.
 LO4 Communicate project ideas and principles to a scientific audience.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning.
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations.
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. However, all proposals will be independently second marked by someone who hasn’t been involved in the delivery of the project. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report being an outline proposal which would be common in requesting funding for a pilot study and would include a hypothesis, supporting evidence aimed to encourage critical analysis of the literature, development of a feasible project idea and understanding. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis, discussion of findings in relation to the field of research.

Students will be offered a re-assessment opportunity in failed assessments in accordance with COPA Appendix C.

Students resitting the oral presentation component will be able to present on their project.

Students resitting the preliminary report will be allowed to re-submit on their project.

Students resitting the module will be required to develop a completely new project with a new supervisor.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

 LO2 Critically evaluate appropriate research techniques, when designing a biomedical sciences research project.
 LO3 Critically appraise relevant literature in the field of biomedical sciences, utilising insights when designing an original research project.
 LO4 Communicate project ideas and principles to a scientific audience.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning.
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations.
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks.

BIOM703
Notes
The purpose of this module is to facilitate the acquisition of advanced knowledge and skills in the planning of an empirical research project in one of the listed research pathways. In addition, students will develop additional skills in critical understanding, knowledge of research techniques, together with presentation and other transferable skills to enhance employability.

The research pathways are:

Biology of Cancer
Biomedical Imaging and Biosensing
Cancer Medicine
Cellular and Molecular Physiology
Medical Sciences
Molecular and Clinical Gastroenterology
Pharmacology and Therapeutics
Neuroscience
Stem Cells, Tissues and Disease

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine provides students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the programme. Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The programme is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interesting in training in biological sciences.

Students will become full members of a research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment. This module along with the 80 credit Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704) module are designed to allow for a parity of experience between the part-time and full-time programmes and clear progression of research education.

This is a 40-credit module that gives direct authentic research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report and preparing an oral presentation. The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal and an oral presentation, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will also be provided with insight into relevant research techniques required for the project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project in Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704). Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given via Science Skills sessions in the BIOM604 module, supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Assessment of the module is via the preliminary report and oral presentation, along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the pathway lead to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address a novel area of research related to one of the programme pathways, but this covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1. To provide students with training in appropriate techniques, research methods and project management in order to conduct a novel research project on aspects of biomedical and translational sciences within an active, first class research environment.

2 To provide the opportunity for students to experience cutting-edge research, and to provide an up-to-date understanding of recent developments and applications in areas of biomedical and translational sciences.

3. To enable students to develop a range of complementary research and employability skills which will provide them with the skills needed to pursue a research career or other professional employment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The MRes in Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine provides students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB). Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The programme is suitable for bioscience graduates, intercalating medical and veterinary students, and science graduates interesting in training in biological sciences. Students will become full members of a research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment.

This is a 40 credit module that gives direct authentic research experience. The module represents the first part of a two-part research project within the MRes in Biomedical Science and Translational Medicine programme. The teaching approach relies upon research-connected and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of scientific reports, scientific presentations, continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).
Outline Syllabus
All students will work on a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project. Projects will offer diverse experiences in research techniques, governance, project management and analysis in an area of Biomedical Sciences and Translational Medicine. Identification of individual development needs by Training Needs Analysis meetings (with supervisor and module lead) will be combined with self-reflections in a skills portfolio. Online resources will support self-directed learning. Students will be given initial training in relevant research techniques required for the project, but will develop the ability to work independently as the project progresses in Biomedical Sciences & Translational Medicine Research Project 2 (BIOM 704). Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation is given via Science Skills sessions in the BIOM604 module, supplemented by project-specific guidance via the academic project supervisor.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The ethos of the learning and teaching in this module is to ensure teaching is informed and refreshed by research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching and supervision will be undertaken by researchers in their specialist area. The teaching method and content is based on a strong knowledge foundation and theoretical application of knowledge, integration of biomedical sciences with research (Research connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students are expected to spend most of their time critically reviewing the literature, planning and piloting their research, and preparing communications i.e. preliminary report, and oral presentations. Regular meetings with the project supervisor(s) are required to ensure students are properly guided and provided with constructive feedback on progress and assignments. Learning will involve self, and supervisor supported, reflection skills activities, followed by evidencing and further portfolio-aided reflection in order to support personalised skills development. In addition to recommended weekly supervisor meetings there will be 2 formal meetings to support portfolio development. Digital resources including videos, workshops and recommended literature also support student learning. The module builds on their understanding of research processes, experimental design, conducting and analysing an empirical research project, research governance and scientific communications via the research project. Laboratory teaching will be undertaken by an experienced member of staff. Once competent, students will undertake the laboratory work under supervision and finally independently or as part of a larger group.

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Supervisors will guide the students through the research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project, in a research report format (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The Departmental research environment and informal teaching sessions - introduce new learning, reinforcing prior learning around research and methodologies and guide the student through their learning process.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. Discussion between students and research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

This teaching and learning strategy, tailored to the specific needs of the student, will help them further develop their specialist research knowledge and understanding, critical thinking skills and research skills. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by submission of a preliminary project report, an oral presentation to peers and members of the Institute and completion of an individual reflective skills portfolio which forms part of the continual assessment. Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft opportunity. The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project. The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. However, all proposals will be independently second marked by someone who hasn’t been involved in the delivery of the project. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report being an outline proposal which would be common in requesting funding for a pilot study and would include a hypothesis, supporting evidence aimed to encourage critical analysis of the literature, development of a feasible project idea and understanding. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis, discussion of findings in relation to the field of research.

Students will be offered a re-assessment opportunity in failed assessments in accordance with COPA Appendix C.

Students resitting the oral presentation component will be able to present on their project.

Students resitting the preliminary report will be allowed to re-submit on their project.

Students resitting the module will be required to develop a completely new project with a new supervisor.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

 LO4 Communicate project ideas and principles to a scientific audience.
Skills

 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations.
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks.

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees, active learning and supporting confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Supervisors will guide the students through the research, planning, safety assessment, execution of the research and writing up of the research project, in a research report format (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The underpinning philosophy for this approach to delivery is independent learning that engages and challenges students in an active learning process (Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The Departmental research environment and informal teaching sessions - introduce new learning, reinforcing prior learning around research and methodologies and guide the student through their learning process.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. Discussion between students and research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

This teaching and learning strategy, tailored to the specific needs of the student, will help them further develop their specialist research knowledge and understanding, critical thinking skills and research skills. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by submission of a preliminary project report, an oral presentation to peers and members of the Institute and completion of an individual reflective skills portfolio which forms part of the continual assessment. Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft opportunity. The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project. The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. However, all proposals will be independently second marked by someone who hasn’t been involved in the delivery of the project. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report being an outline proposal which would be common in requesting funding for a pilot study and would include a hypothesis, supporting evidence aimed to encourage critical analysis of the literature, development of a feasible project idea and understanding. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis, discussion of findings in relation to the field of research.

Students will be offered a re-assessment opportunity in failed assessments in accordance with COPA Appendix C.

Students resitting the oral presentation component will be able to present on their project.

Students resitting the preliminary report will be allowed to re-submit on their project.

Students resitting the module will be required to develop a completely new project with a new supervisor.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Plan an original research study in the field of biomedical sciences within a specified time frame.
 LO2 Critically evaluate appropriate research techniques, when designing a biomedical sciences research project.
 LO3 Critically appraise relevant literature in the field of biomedical sciences, utilising insights when designing an original research project.
 LO4 Communicate project ideas and principles to a scientific audience.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning.
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations.
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning.
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks.
